title: Pouring Water — Pitcher to Glasses
description: The child pours water from one pitcher into two glasses evenly, developing estimation of volume and refined motor control.
instructions:
1. Place a small pitcher filled halfway with water and two empty glasses on a tray.
2. Demonstrate pouring water evenly into both glasses.
3. Compare the water level — are they the same?
4. Pour both glasses back into the pitcher.
5. Let the child practice.
6. Clean up any spills with the sponge.

slides.heading: Pouring Water
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this fun thing we're going to do! We're going to practice pouring water, and it's going to be super cool.

slides.setup_instructions: Fill the pitcher halfway. Place everything on the tray.
slides.mascot_explanation: We need some special things for our pouring game! See this little jug? That's a pitcher, and we'll pour water from it. We also need two cups that look just the same, and a tray to keep everything tidy. Oh, and a sponge for any little drips!

slides.text: Carry the tray to the table. 'Today we'll pour into two glasses and try to make them equal!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's get our special things ready! Can you help carry this tray over to our table? We're going to try and pour water so both cups have the same amount.

slides.text: Pour slowly into the first glass — about halfway. Then pour into the second glass.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's pour! Hold the pitcher gently and tip it just a little bit to fill up the first cup. Then, we'll do the same for the second cup. Try to make the water go in nice and slow!

slides.text: Look at both glasses side by side. 'Are they the same? Do we need to add a little more to one?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at our cups! Can you see if the water in both cups is the same height? Sometimes we need to add just a tiny bit more to one cup to make them match perfectly.

slides.prompt: Practice pouring evenly into both glasses 3 times. Can you make them match?
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the super pourer! We're going to practice filling up both cups so they have the same amount of water. You get to try this three times – you can do it!

slides.text: Pour the water out. Dry everything. Return the tray to the shelf.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child pour approximately equal amounts into two glasses?
slides.mascot_explanation: We did it! We poured all the water back, and now we'll dry everything up nice and neat. You did such a great job pouring water so evenly into both cups!

parent_notes: This extends the basic pouring exercise by adding the challenge of equal distribution — an early math concept. Don't worry about perfect measurement; the child is developing the eye for estimation. Use real glass when possible — it teaches respect and care for materials.

title: Sandpaper Letter — a (short vowel)
description: Introduction to the first vowel sandpaper letter 'a' (short sound as in 'apple'). The child learns the short vowel sound through tracing and I Spy.
instructions:
1. Present sandpaper letter 'a' (on blue background for vowel).
2. Trace while saying /a/ (short a, as in apple). Repeat 3 times.
3. Child traces and says the sound.
4. Three-period lesson: naming, recognition, recall.
5. I Spy with /a/ objects: apple, ant, ax, alligator.
6. Review: show 's', 'm', and 'a' together.

slides.heading: Sandpaper Letter
slides.mascot_explanation: Hi friend! Today we're going to learn a super special letter sound. It's a vowel sound, and it sounds like the beginning of "apple"! We'll learn all about it together.

slides.setup_instructions: Place letter 'a' on the tray. Note the different background color — this is a vowel!
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these fun things we get to use! We have a bumpy letter 'a' that we'll trace, and some other letters too. We also have some cool toys and pictures, like a yummy apple and a tiny ant!

slides.text: 'This letter has a different color background because it's a special kind of letter called a vowel!'
slides.mascot_explanation: See this letter 'a' on the blue paper? That blue means it's a special kind of letter called a vowel. Vowels are like the super stars of letters, and they make special sounds!

slides.text: Trace 'a' with two fingers. Say /a/ (short, as in apple). 'aaa — apple!' Repeat 3 times.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's get our fingers ready! We're going to trace the bumpy letter 'a' with two fingers, like this. As we trace, we'll say its sound: "aaa"! It sounds like "aaa-apple"! Let's trace and say it three times.

slides.text: Three-period lesson. Then review all three: 'Show me /s/.' 'Where is /a/?' 'What sound is this?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Great tracing! Now, I'll point to the letters, and you tell me their sounds. Can you show me the sound for 's'? And now, where is the letter that makes the "aaa" sound? What sound does this letter make?

slides.prompt: I Spy with /a/ objects! Then sort: which objects start with /s/, /m/, or /a/?
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's play a fun game called "I Spy"! We'll look at all our pictures and toys. Can you find things that start with the "aaa" sound, like an apple or an ant? Then we'll see if they also start with the 's' or 'm' sounds we know.

slides.text: 'You now know three sounds: /s/, /m/, and /a/! Soon you'll put them together to make words!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child identify the short /a/ sound and distinguish it from /s/ and /m/?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a fantastic job today! You learned three special sounds: /s/, /m/, and the "aaa" sound for our vowel 'a'. Soon we'll put these sounds together to make real words! That's so exciting!

parent_notes: This is the first vowel! In Montessori, vowels are on blue cards and consonants on pink (or vice versa, depending on the set). Always teach the SHORT vowel sound first (/a/ as in apple, not the long sound as in 'ape'). With s, m, and a, the child can soon build their first words: 'am', 'Sam', 'mas'.

title: Number Rods — Full Set 1-10
description: Completing the number rod sequence with rods 8, 9, and 10. The child builds the full stair and practices counting to ten.
instructions:
1. Review rods 1-7 quickly.
2. Introduce rod 8. Count segments together.
3. Introduce rod 9, then rod 10.
4. Build the complete stair 1-10.
5. Count from 1 to 10 touching each rod.
6. Play 'Give me' game: 'Give me the rod that shows 8.'

slides.heading: Number Rods
slides.mascot_explanation: Look, friend! We're going to play with special blocks called number rods today. They help us learn about numbers, like how many fingers you have on one hand!

slides.setup_instructions: You'll need a large workspace — rod 10 is 1 meter long! Lay out the mat.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these colorful rods! We need all of them to make a big, tall tower of numbers. We also need this big mat to give our rods lots of space to play.

slides.text: Quick review: build the stair 1-7 together.
slides.mascot_explanation: First, let's remember the number rods we already know. See how they make a little stair? We'll put them together just like we did before!

slides.text: Introduce 8, 9, 10 one at a time. Count each rod's segments carefully.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, we get to meet some new, bigger rods! We'll look at the rod for number 8, then the one for 9, and finally the super long one for 10. We'll count all the little parts on each one together.

slides.text: Complete the stair! Stand back and admire. 'Look how it grows from 1 all the way to 10!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, we get to build the whole number stair, from the tiny rod for 1 all the way up to the giant rod for 10! It's going to be so tall and look like a rainbow.

slides.prompt: 'Give me' game: 'Give me eight!' 'Give me the rod that comes after six!' Take turns.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's play a fun game! I'll say a number, like "Give me eight!" and you find the rod that shows the number 8. Then you can ask me to find one too!

slides.text: Return each rod to the shelf. 'You can count to TEN!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child build the full stair and count to 10?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! You built the whole number stair and counted all the way to ten – that's amazing! Putting all the rods back helps us remember them for next time.

parent_notes: The full number rod stair is impressive — rod 10 is one meter long! This gives the child a truly concrete sense of how 10 is ten times as much as 1. Once the stair is mastered, the child can work with it independently. Extensions include finding combinations that make 10 (1+9, 2+8, etc.).

title: The Globe — Europe, Asia, and Australia
description: Continuing continent exploration with Europe, Asia, and Australia/Oceania on the Montessori globe.
instructions:
1. Review North America, South America, and Africa on the globe.
2. Introduce Europe (red): 'Europe is here — many countries close together.'
3. Introduce Asia (yellow): 'Asia is the biggest continent!'
4. Introduce Australia (brown): 'Australia is the smallest continent — and it's an island!'
5. Play 'Find the continent': name one, child points to it.
6. Count: 'We've learned 6 continents! There's one more — Antarctica!'

slides.heading: The Globe
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this big round ball! It's called a globe, and it shows us all the lands and oceans on our whole world. Today, we're going to learn about some special big lands called continents!

slides.setup_instructions: Place the globe at the child's level. Have review cards from last lesson.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this beautiful globe! This is our special tool to help us learn about the world. We also have some picture cards that help us remember the names of the lands we already know.

slides.text: Review: 'Show me North America. Where is Africa? Find South America!' Praise each correct answer.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's do a quick check of the lands we already know on our globe. Can you point to North America, where we live? Great job! Now, can you find Africa and then South America? You're doing so well!

slides.text: Europe (red): 'This is Europe. Lots of countries are packed in here!' Let the child touch it.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's find a new land called Europe. See this part of the globe? It's colored red. Europe has many countries all snuggled up close together, like friends holding hands.

slides.text: Asia (yellow): 'This is Asia — it's the BIGGEST continent!' Australia (brown): 'And here's the smallest!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Next, let's look at this super big yellow land – that's Asia, the biggest continent of all! And look at this small brown land here; that's Australia, which is also an island because it's surrounded by water.

slides.prompt: Spin the globe, stop it, and name the continent your finger lands on! Play 5 rounds.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's play a fun game! We'll spin the globe and then close our eyes and point. Wherever your finger lands, we'll try to say the name of that continent together. Let's do this five times!

slides.text: 'Six continents learned! Next we'll visit Antarctica — the frozen continent!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child locate and name at least 4 of 6 continents introduced?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay! We have learned about six amazing continents already! You did such a great job finding them on the globe. Next time, we'll learn about the super cold continent called Antarctica!

parent_notes: Don't worry about perfection — we'll review continents all year long. The globe-spinning game makes it playful. For older kindergartners, you can start matching continent shapes to the puzzle map. Each continent's color is consistent across all Montessori materials, which helps with recognition.

title: Read-Aloud: The Very Hungry Caterpillar
description: Shared reading of Eric Carle's 'The Very Hungry Caterpillar' with discussion about counting, days of the week, and metamorphosis.
instructions:
1. Show the cover. 'What do you think this story is about?'
2. Read aloud, pausing to count the foods on each page.
3. Point to the holes in the pages — let the child poke fingers through.
4. After reading, review the days of the week.
5. Discuss: 'What happened to the caterpillar at the end?'
6. Sequence: egg → caterpillar → cocoon → butterfly.
materials_needed: The Very Hungry Caterpillar by Eric Carle
Optional: real or plastic butterfly life cycle figures

slides.heading: Read-Aloud
slides.subheading: The Very Hungry Caterpillar by Eric Carle
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this pretty picture! This is the cover of our special book, "The Very Hungry Caterpillar." It looks like a colorful bug is going to be the star of our story today!

slides.setup_instructions: Sit together in a cozy reading spot.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, we have our book ready, and maybe some special little toys too! We need our cozy spot to read, so let's snuggle up together. This is going to be so much fun!

slides.text: Cover talk: 'What do you see? What do you think will happen in this story?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's look at the front of the book. What do you see? Can you guess what our story might be about? Maybe it's about a little bug who is very, very hungry!

slides.text: Read aloud. Count the foods together on each page. 'On Monday he ate through ONE apple...'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to read our story! As we turn the pages, let's count all the yummy things the caterpillar eats. We'll count them together, just like this: one, two, three!

slides.text: Let the child interact — poke fingers through the holes, count along with you.
slides.mascot_explanation: See these little holes in the pages? Let's poke our fingers through them! It feels so funny, doesn't it? We can count the holes too, and pretend we are the caterpillar munching through!

slides.prompt: After reading: 'Can you remember what he ate on Monday? Tuesday? Wednesday?' Review the days.
slides.mascot_explanation: We finished the story! Can you remember what the caterpillar ate on Monday? How about Tuesday? Let's say the days of the week together and remember all the food!

slides.text: Discuss the life cycle: egg, caterpillar, cocoon, butterfly! 'What a transformation!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child retell the basic sequence of the story?
slides.mascot_explanation: Our little caterpillar changed so much! First, it was a tiny egg, then a wiggly caterpillar, then it took a nap in a cocoon, and guess what it became? A beautiful butterfly! You did such a great job listening and learning!

parent_notes: This beloved book reinforces counting (1 apple, 2 pears, 3 plums...), days of the week, and the life cycle of a butterfly. It connects beautifully to science and math. The repetitive structure supports early literacy. If your child loves it, read it multiple times — familiarity breeds confidence and vocabulary growth.

title: Pink Tower & Brown Stair — Combined Extension
description: Combining the Pink Tower and Brown Stair to explore patterns and creative building. The child discovers new ways to arrange the two materials together.
instructions:
1. Build the Pink Tower and Brown Stair side by side.
2. Show how the smallest cube matches the thinnest prism.
3. Create a combined pattern: alternate tower cubes and stair prisms.
4. Let the child experiment with their own designs.
5. Encourage: 'What else can you build with these?'
6. Photograph any creative constructions.

slides.heading: Pink Tower & Brown Stair
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this fun lesson! We're going to play with the Pink Tower and the Brown Stair and build something super cool together. It’s going to be a building adventure!

slides.setup_instructions: Carry all pieces to the mat. Start by building each set correctly.
slides.mascot_explanation: We need some special things for our building today! See these big blocks? That's the Pink Tower! And these long, colorful pieces are the Brown Stair. We also need this big mat to build on. Can you ask a grown-up to help you carry them to the mat?

slides.text: Build the Pink Tower. Build the Brown Stair beside it. 'Look, they match! The biggest cube matches the thickest prism.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's build! We're going to put all the big pink squares together to make a tall tower, and all the long brown sticks together to make a staircase right next to it. Look how the biggest pink block is just the same size as the biggest brown stick!

slides.text: Show: place the smallest cube on the thinnest prism. They're the same width! 'How interesting!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's try something neat! Can you find the tiniest pink block and the tiniest brown stick? We're going to put the tiny pink block right on top of the tiny brown stick. See? They fit together perfectly because they are the same width!

slides.text: 'Now you can build whatever you like with all 20 pieces! What can you create?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, we have so many blocks and sticks now! We can use all of them to build anything we imagine. What kind of amazing thing do you want to build today? Let’s be creative!

slides.prompt: Free building! Combine cubes and prisms into new structures. Try a road, a city, a maze!
slides.mascot_explanation: This is your special building time! You can use all the pink blocks and brown sticks to make anything you want. Maybe you can build a long road, or a whole city, or even a maze! Let your imagination fly!

slides.text: Admire the creation. Take a photo if you like! Then return all pieces to the shelf.
slides.mastery_check: Does the child explore creatively and handle materials with care?
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at the amazing thing you built! You were such a wonderful builder. If you want, we can take a picture of your creation to remember it. Then, let's carefully put all the blocks and sticks back where they belong.

parent_notes: Montessori extensions combine materials in new ways. The child discovers mathematical relationships: the smallest pink cube has the same dimensions as the cross-section of the thinnest brown prism. These 'aha' moments are the magic of Montessori materials. Let the child's creativity guide the construction — there is no wrong answer.

title: Sandpaper Letter — t
description: Introduction to sandpaper letter 't' and its sound /t/. Review of all learned letters: s, m, a, t.
instructions:
1. Present sandpaper letter 't'.
2. Trace while saying /t/ (quick, crisp sound). Repeat 3 times.
3. Child traces and says the sound.
4. Three-period lesson.
5. Review all four letters: s, m, a, t.
6. I Spy with /t/ objects: top, tiger, tape, tree, train.

slides.heading: Sandpaper Letter
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! We're going to learn about a new letter today. It's called 't', and it makes a special sound like "tuh"!

items: Letters s, m, a for review
slides.setup_instructions: Place 't' on the tray. Keep previously learned letters nearby.
slides.mascot_explanation: Here are the special things we need for our learning fun! We have a bumpy letter 't' that feels so cool, and we also have our other letters we learned before, like 's', 'm', and 'a'. We'll also look at some fun toys that start with our new sound!

slides.text: Trace 't': straight line down, then cross. Say '/t/' — it's a quick, crisp sound.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's feel our new letter 't'! We trace it with our finger, like this: straight down, and then a line across the top. As we trace, we say the sound it makes: /t/, /t/, /t/. It's a quick little sound!

slides.text: Child traces and repeats. Three-period lesson for 't'.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to feel the bumpy 't' and make its sound! Trace it slowly with your finger and say "/t/" just like we practiced. You're doing so great feeling the letter and making its sound!

slides.text: Review all four: lay out s, m, a, t. 'Show me /t/.' 'Where is /a/?' 'What sound is this?'
slides.mascot_explanation: We learned so many letters! Let's look at them all. We have 's', 'm', 'a', and our new friend 't'. Can you point to the letter 't' when I ask for it? What sound does 'a' make? We're remembering them all!

slides.prompt: I Spy with /t/ objects! Then sort all objects by their beginning sounds: /s/, /m/, /a/, or /t/.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's play a fun game called I Spy! We'll look for things that start with the /t/ sound, like a top or a tiger. Then, we'll put all our toys into groups based on the first sound they make. You're a super sound detective!

slides.text: 'Four sounds! s, m, a, t. You're building a great collection!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child trace and identify all four letters?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, you did it! You learned all about the letter 't' and its sound /t/, and you remembered 's', 'm', and 'a' too! You are so smart and you know four special letter sounds now!

parent_notes: With s, m, a, and t, the child now knows enough sounds to build their first words with the moveable alphabet! Words like 'mat', 'sat', 'am', 'at', 'Sam', 'Tam'. We'll start word building soon. Keep reviewing — frequent, short practice is better than long, infrequent sessions.

title: Sandpaper Numerals — 6, 7, 8
description: Introduction to sandpaper numerals 6, 7, and 8 with tracing and three-period lessons.
instructions:
1. Review numerals 1-5 quickly.
2. Introduce 6: trace while saying 'six.' Three-period lesson.
3. Introduce 7: trace while saying 'seven.' Three-period lesson.
4. Introduce 8: trace while saying 'eight.' Three-period lesson.
5. Lay out all 8 numerals for random recall.
6. Match numerals 6, 7, 8 to their number rods.

slides.heading: Sandpaper Numerals
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this! We're going to learn about some new numbers today, the numbers six, seven, and eight. These are special numbers that help us count all sorts of fun things!

slides.setup_instructions: Review 1-5 first, then present 6, 7, 8.
slides.mascot_explanation: To do our number fun, we need a few things. We have special number cards that feel a little bumpy, and we also have some colorful sticks called number rods. Let's ask a grown-up to help us get them ready on a tray!

slides.text: Quick review of 1-5: shuffle and have the child name each.
slides.mascot_explanation: First, we're going to quickly say the numbers we already know, from one to five. Can you help me remember them? We'll point to them and say their names super fast!

slides.text: Introduce 6: trace with two fingers, say 'six.' Curl from the top. Child traces.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's meet the number six! Feel the bumpy number on the card with your fingers. We're going to trace it together, going around and down, and say "six" out loud. You can do it!

slides.text: Introduce 7, then 8. Three-period lesson for each new numeral.
slides.mascot_explanation: Next, we'll do the same thing for the number seven and then the number eight. We'll feel them, trace them with our fingers, and say their names. It's like learning new friends' names!

slides.prompt: Match numerals 6, 7, 8 to their number rods. Then do a full shuffle of all 8 numerals.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now for some fun matching! Can you find the number card that looks like a six and put it next to the right colored stick? We'll do this for six, seven, and eight, and then mix them all up to play a guessing game!

slides.text: 'You can recognize eight different numerals now!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child identify numerals 1-8?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did it! You can now find and say six, seven, and eight! You are so smart and learned so many new numbers today. Isn't it cool that you can recognize eight different numbers now?

parent_notes: We add 3 numerals at a time now since the child has the pattern down. If your child struggles with 6, 7, and 8 in one lesson, slow down — introduce just one or two. The three-period lesson format (naming → recognition → recall) is always your guide. Watch for reversals of 6 and 9 — this is normal and will resolve with practice.

title: Nature Walk — Collecting and Classifying
description: Second nature walk focused on collecting items and classifying them by attributes: color, texture, size, or type.
instructions:
1. Go on a nature walk with collection basket.
2. Collect 6-8 diverse items.
3. Return to the work area.
4. Classify items by color: 'Put all the green things here, all the brown things here.'
5. Reclassify by texture: rough vs. smooth.
6. Reclassify by type: plant parts vs. mineral/rock.
7. Discuss: 'The same objects can be sorted different ways!'

slides.heading: Nature Walk
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at that! We're going on a special nature walk today to find cool things outside. We'll be like little scientists looking closely at everything we find!

slides.setup_instructions: Pack the basket. Prepare sorting mats for return.
slides.mascot_explanation: For our adventure, we need a few things. This is a basket to hold all the treasures we find outside, and this is a magnifying glass to see tiny details up close. Let's ask a grown-up to help us get these ready!

slides.text: 'Today let's collect items and sort them when we get back! Look for different colors and textures.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Today, we're going to be explorers! We'll go outside and find some interesting things, and when we come back, we'll sort them like a game. We'll look for things that are different colors and feel different.

slides.text: Walk slowly. Collect 6-8 items. Talk about each find.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's go for a slow walk outside, like little detectives! We need to find about six or eight special treasures from nature, and we can talk about each one as we find it. What a fun treasure hunt!

slides.text: Back inside, sort by COLOR first. Then re-sort by TEXTURE (rough vs. smooth). Then by TYPE.
slides.mascot_explanation: When we come back inside, we'll play a sorting game! First, we'll put all the things that are the same color together, then we'll sort them by if they feel bumpy or smooth, and then by what kind of thing they are.

slides.prompt: Can you think of your OWN way to sort these items? Big and small? Heavy and light?
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the super sorter! Can you think of another way to put all our nature treasures into groups? Maybe we can sort them by if they are big or small, or if they feel heavy or light. You can do it!

slides.text: 'The same objects sorted three different ways! Scientists classify things just like we did.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child sort objects by at least 2 different attributes?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a great job sorting our nature treasures! We learned that the same things can be sorted in lots of different ways, just like real scientists do. You were an amazing nature explorer and sorter!

parent_notes: Classification is a fundamental science skill. The key insight is that the same set of objects can be sorted multiple ways depending on the attribute you choose. This builds flexible thinking. Keep a nature shelf where collections can be displayed and revisited.

title: Singing — Head, Shoulders, Knees and Toes
description: Learning action songs that combine music with body awareness. 'Head, Shoulders, Knees and Toes' teaches body parts through movement and rhythm.
instructions:
1. Sing 'Head, Shoulders, Knees and Toes' slowly with motions.
2. Touch each body part as you sing.
3. Repeat faster each time.
4. Add a round where you whisper one body part instead of singing.
5. Try 'If You're Happy and You Know It' as a second song.
6. Let the child suggest motions for the second song.
materials_needed: Optional: picture cards of body parts

slides.heading: Singing
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look! We're going to sing a super fun song called "Head, Shoulders, Knees and Toes"! It's a song that helps us learn about our bodies and move them all around.

slides.setup_instructions: Clear some space to stand and move freely.
slides.mascot_explanation: To sing our song, we need a nice big space to wiggle and jiggle! Let's make sure we can stand up tall and move our arms and legs without bumping into anything.

slides.text: Stand facing the child. 'We're going to sing and move our bodies!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, now we're going to sing together and do some fun actions! I'll sing the song slowly, and you can sing along with me and do the moves.

slides.text: Sing slowly: 'Head, shoulders, knees and toes, knees and toes!' Touch each part as you sing.
slides.mascot_explanation: Listen closely! We're going to sing "Head, shoulders, knees and toes," and as we sing each word, we'll touch that part of our body. So, when I say "head," you touch your head!

slides.text: Repeat getting faster each time. Laugh when it gets silly-fast!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's try singing it a little faster! We'll keep singing and touching our body parts, and it's going to get faster and faster, maybe even a little silly! Let's laugh when it gets super speedy!

slides.prompt: Try whispering 'head' instead of singing it — just touch it silently! Can you remember all the parts?
slides.mascot_explanation: This is a fun game! We'll sing the song again, but this time, when we get to the word "head," we'll whisper it super quietly and just touch our head. Can you remember all the other parts and touch them like before?

slides.text: Sing one more time at a comfortable speed. 'Great singing and moving today!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child sing along and identify the body parts?
slides.mascot_explanation: We did such a great job singing and moving our bodies today! You were amazing at touching all your body parts. Give yourself a big clap for being such a fantastic singer!

parent_notes: Action songs connect music with kinesthetic learning. The speeding-up challenge builds processing speed and coordination. The 'silent' round (touching but not singing a body part) builds auditory memory. These songs are perfect for transitions and energy breaks throughout the school day.

title: Spooning — Dry Transfer
description: The child uses a spoon to transfer dry beans from one bowl to another, refining fine motor control and concentration.
instructions:
1. Place two bowls on a tray — one with dry beans, one empty.
2. Demonstrate scooping beans with a spoon and transferring to the empty bowl.
3. Show how to hold the spoon steady while carrying it across.
4. Let the child transfer all the beans.
5. Count how many scoops it took.
6. Sweep up any spilled beans.

slides.heading: Spooning
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! We're going to play a fun game called "Spooning" today with some beans. It's all about moving things carefully with a spoon.

slides.setup_instructions: Fill one bowl with dry beans. Place both bowls and spoon on the tray.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's see what we need for our game! We have two bowls, a big spoon for scooping, and some yummy-looking beans. There's also a tray to keep everything tidy and a little broom for any tiny spills. Can you ask a grown-up to help you find all these things?

slides.text: 'Today we're going to move these beans using a spoon — one scoop at a time!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Today, we're going to use our special spoon to move these little beans from one bowl to the other. It's like a treasure hunt, but with beans!

slides.text: Demonstrate: scoop a spoonful, hold it level, carry across, pour gently into the empty bowl.
slides.mascot_explanation: Watch me! I'm going to scoop up some beans, hold my spoon very still, and walk it over to the other bowl. Then, I'll gently tip the spoon to let the beans fall in.

slides.text: 'Your turn! Scoop carefully and carry the spoon straight across. Try not to drop any beans.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to try! You get to be the bean mover. Scoop up some beans with your spoon and try to carry them all the way across without them falling out. You can do it!

slides.prompt: Transfer all the beans! Count your scoops. Then transfer them back. Did it take the same number?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, you did it! Now, let's count how many scoops it took to move all the beans. Then, we can try moving them back! It's like a little game to see if it takes the same number of scoops.

slides.text: Sweep any spilled beans. Return the tray to the shelf.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child transfer beans with minimal spilling?
slides.mascot_explanation: Great job moving all those beans! If any little beans rolled away, we can use our special broom to sweep them up. Then, we'll put our tray back neatly so it's ready for our next fun game.

parent_notes: Spooning is a key practical life skill that directly prepares the child for self-feeding and cooking. The concentration required to keep the spoon level builds focus. Vary the challenge: start with large beans, progress to smaller lentils or rice. This is a wonderful shelf work for independent practice.

title: I Spy — Review (s, m, a, t) and Oral Language
description: I Spy game reviewing all four learned sounds. Extended oral language practice with descriptive vocabulary.
instructions:
1. Gather objects for all four sounds: s, m, a, t (3 each = 12 objects).
2. Play I Spy, mixing all four sounds.
3. When the child identifies an object, ask them to describe it: 'Tell me about the star. What does it look like?'
4. Practice full sentences: 'The star is yellow and has five points.'
5. Sort objects by beginning sound into four groups.
6. Celebrate the growing sound knowledge!
materials_needed: Objects for sounds s, m, a, t (3 each)
Four sorting mats with letter labels

slides.heading: I Spy Review
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! We're going to play a super fun game called "I Spy" today. We'll be listening for special sounds that help us read words, like the sounds in "sun," "moon," "apple," and "tiger."

slides.setup_instructions: Mix all objects together on a large tray.
slides.mascot_explanation: To play our game, we need some special treasures! See these little toys? We have three for the "s" sound, three for "m," three for "a," and three for "t." We also have some colorful mats to help us sort them later. Can you ask a grown-up to help you find all these little treasures?

slides.text: Play I Spy mixing all four sounds: 'I spy something that starts with /t/!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time to play "I Spy"! I'll give you a clue, like "I spy something that starts with the /t/ sound." You'll look really hard at all the treasures and try to find the one that matches the sound. It's like a treasure hunt for sounds!

slides.text: When found, extend: 'Tell me about this tiger. What color is it? Is it big or small?'
slides.mascot_explanation: When you find the treasure, like a tiger, we'll talk all about it! We can ask questions like, "What color is the tiger?" or "Is it big or small?" This helps us learn new words and how to describe things.

slides.text: Practice sentences: 'The tiger is orange and has black stripes.' Model rich language.
slides.mascot_explanation: After we talk about the treasure, we'll make a whole sentence about it. For example, we could say, "The tiger is orange and has black stripes." This is a great way to practice using our talking words!

slides.prompt: Sort all 12 objects into 4 groups by their beginning sound. Put /s/ objects here, /m/ here...
slides.mascot_explanation: Now for a super fun part! We get to be detectives and sort all our treasures. We'll put all the things that start with the "s" sound together, then all the "m" things, then "a," and finally "t." It's like putting puzzle pieces in the right spot!

slides.text: Count how many objects in each group. 'You can hear four different sounds now!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child sort objects by beginning sound with 80% accuracy?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a great job listening for all those sounds and sorting the treasures! You found so many things and sorted them perfectly. You can hear four different sounds now – that's amazing!

parent_notes: The oral language extension is crucial. Montessori emphasizes that rich oral language precedes reading and writing. Model descriptive, complete sentences. The sorting activity adds a visual-organizational component. Keep collecting miniature objects — the richer your collection, the more versatile your I Spy games.

title: Sandpaper Numerals — 9 and 10; Full Review
description: Completing the sandpaper numerals with 9 and 10, then a comprehensive review and matching with all number rods.
instructions:
1. Review numerals 1-8.
2. Introduce 9: trace and say 'nine.' Three-period lesson.
3. Introduce 10: trace both digits while saying 'ten.'
4. Full review: shuffle all 10 numerals.
5. Match all numerals to their number rods.
6. 'Now you know ALL the numerals from 1 to 10!'

slides.heading: Sandpaper Numerals
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this fun title! We are going to learn about numbers that look like they are made of sandpaper. We're going to learn the numbers nine and ten today, and then we'll have all the numbers from one to ten!

slides.setup_instructions: You'll need ample space to match all 10 numerals with all 10 rods.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, we need lots of things for our number fun! We have special sandpaper numbers from one all the way to ten. We also have these long sticks called number rods, and a big mat to spread everything out on. Can you ask a grown-up to help you find all these special things?

slides.text: Review 1-8 with quick recall. Shuffle and have the child name each.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's remember our numbers first! We already know numbers one through eight. Let's say them together and then mix them up to see if you can tell me what each one is. You're so good at remembering!

slides.text: Introduce 9: 'Almost like 6 but upside down!' Trace and say 'nine.' Three-period lesson.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's learn a new number: nine! It looks a little like the number six, but it's upside down. Let's trace the bumpy number nine with your finger and say "nine" together. You can do it!

slides.text: Introduce 10: 'This needs TWO digits — a 1 and a 0 together make ten!' Trace both.
slides.mascot_explanation: Next, we have a number that uses two friends to make it: number ten! It's a tall number one and a round number zero standing together. Let's trace them both and say "ten" out loud. Great job!

slides.prompt: Match all 10 numerals to their number rods! Place each numeral at the end of its rod.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now for the super fun part! We get to match all our sandpaper numbers to their number rods. Find the number that goes with each stick and put them together. It's like a puzzle, and you are so good at puzzles!

slides.text: 'You know every numeral from 1 to 10! That's a huge accomplishment!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child identify and match all numerals 1-10?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay! You did it! You learned all the numbers from one to ten! That's amazing and a really big accomplishment. You can now count and know all the numbers, just like a big kid!

parent_notes: The 10 numeral is significant because it requires TWO symbols. This is a sneak peek at the concept of place value, which will be explored deeply with the golden beads later. Watch for 6/9 confusion — teach the child that 6 has a 'belly' on the bottom and 9 has a 'belly' on the top. Celebrate this milestone!

title: Land and Water Forms — Peninsula and Gulf
description: Second pair of opposite land and water forms: peninsula and gulf. The child explores these through the land/water trays and drawing.
instructions:
1. Review island and lake with the trays.
2. Introduce the peninsula tray: 'A peninsula is land surrounded by water on three sides.'
3. Introduce the gulf tray: 'A gulf is water surrounded by land on three sides.'
4. Pour water into each to demonstrate.
5. 'Peninsula and gulf are opposites — just like island and lake!'
6. Draw and label each form.

slides.heading: Land and Water Forms
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at that! Today we're going to learn about some super cool shapes on our Earth called land and water forms. We'll learn about a peninsula and a gulf, and they are like opposites, just like you and your best friend!

items: Island and lake trays for review
slides.setup_instructions: Set up all four trays on towels. Have water and drawing materials ready.
slides.mascot_explanation: Oh, look at all the fun things we need for our adventure today! We have special trays with land and water in them, and we'll need some water to play with. We also have paper and pencils so we can draw the amazing things we learn. Can you ask your grown-up to help you find all these things?

slides.text: Review: 'What is an island?' 'What is a lake?' Let the child explain.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's remember what we already know! Do you remember what an island is? It's land all by itself in the water. And what about a lake? That's water all by itself, surrounded by land. Tell me all about them!

slides.text: Peninsula: 'Land that sticks out into the water — water on three sides, land on one.' Pour water around it.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's look at this new shape! See this land here? It's like a finger of land that sticks out into the water, and water is all around it on three sides. This special shape is called a peninsula, and we're going to pour some water around it to see it better!

slides.text: Gulf: 'Water that reaches into the land — land on three sides, water opens on one.' Pour water in.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is another new shape, and it's the opposite of the peninsula! See how the water is reaching way into the land, and the land is all around it on three sides? That's called a gulf, and we'll pour some water in to show how it fits inside the land.

slides.prompt: Draw a peninsula: land sticking out with water around three sides. Then draw a gulf: water going into the land.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be an artist! We're going to draw the shapes we learned about. First, draw the peninsula, that finger of land sticking out with water on three sides. Then, draw the gulf, with the water reaching into the land on three sides. You can do it!

slides.text: 'You know four land and water forms now: island, lake, peninsula, and gulf!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child define peninsula and gulf and identify them as opposites?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, you did it! You learned about four amazing land and water shapes today: island, lake, peninsula, and gulf! You are such a smart explorer, and you can even tell me what a peninsula and a gulf are now. That's so awesome!

parent_notes: Land and water forms are always presented in pairs of opposites. The opposite relationship helps children understand: where land pushes out (peninsula), water can push in (gulf). Real-world examples make this concrete: Florida is a peninsula; the Gulf of Mexico is a gulf. Point these out on a map or globe!

title: Painting — Exploring Watercolors
description: Introduction to watercolor painting. The child learns how to use a brush, mix colors with water, and paint freely.
instructions:
1. Set up: watercolor tray, water cup, brush, paper, paper towel.
2. Demonstrate: dip brush in water, touch a color, paint a stroke.
3. Show: rinse brush before changing colors.
4. Let the child explore freely.
5. Talk about what happens when colors mix on the paper.
6. Allow the painting to dry. Display.

slides.heading: Painting
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at that! We're going to have so much fun painting today, and we'll learn all about colors that sparkle with water!

slides.setup_instructions: Cover the workspace. Put on a smock. Fill the water cup. Lay out materials.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's get our special painting things ready! We have a big paint box with lots of colors, special thick paper, a soft brush, a cup for water, a towel to dry our brush, and a smock to keep our clothes clean. Can you ask a grown-up to help you find all these things and get your painting spot ready?

slides.text: 'Today we're going to paint with watercolors!' Show how to put on the smock first.
slides.mascot_explanation: First, let's put on our smock! This is like a superhero cape for painting, and it will keep your clothes nice and dry while we make beautiful art.

slides.text: Demonstrate: 'Dip your brush in water. Touch a color gently. Paint on the paper. See the color flow!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's get our brush ready for some color! We'll dip the brush in the water just a little bit, then gently touch a color in the paint box, and watch the color jump onto the paper!

slides.text: 'When you want a new color: rinse, rinse, rinse in the water. Dab on the paper towel. Then touch the new color.'
slides.mascot_explanation: When we want to try a new color, we need to give our brush a little bath in the water cup to wash off the old color, and then pat it dry on the paper towel. This way, our new colors stay super bright and don't get all mixed up!

slides.prompt: Paint whatever you like! Try different colors. What happens when two colors meet on the paper?
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the artist! You can paint anything you dream up, and let's see what happens when we let two colors touch each other on the paper. It's like a colorful surprise party!

slides.text: Rinse and lay out the brush. Pour out the dirty water. Let the painting dry flat.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child use the brush, rinse between colors, and paint on the paper?
slides.mascot_explanation: Great job, artist! You did it! You painted with your brush, cleaned it up for new colors, and made a beautiful picture. We'll let your amazing painting dry so we can hang it up for everyone to see!

parent_notes: Watercolor is a perfect first painting medium — clean-up is easy and the transparent colors are beautiful. Focus on PROCESS: how to hold the brush, how to rinse, how to control the water amount. The child's painting may look like colored blobs — that's perfect! The goal is exploration, not representation. Display all artwork to show it is valued.

title: Red Rods — Introduction
description: Introduction to the Montessori Red Rods. The child arranges 10 rods from longest to shortest, developing visual discrimination of length.
instructions:
1. Carry each rod to the mat one at a time, starting with the longest.
2. Scatter rods randomly on the mat.
3. Find the longest rod. Place it at the top.
4. Find the next longest. Place below the first, aligned at the left.
5. Continue until all 10 rods form a stair.
6. Run hand along the stair ends to feel the graduation.

slides.heading: The Red Rods
slides.mascot_explanation: Look, friend! We're going to learn about something super cool called the Red Rods today! They help us see how things can be long, and then a little bit shorter, and even shorter still!

slides.setup_instructions: The longest rod is 1 meter! Ensure plenty of space.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these special red rods! We need these for our building game today. We also need a big, comfy mat to play on, so we have lots of space to make our red rod tower.

slides.text: Carry the longest rod with two hands. 'This is the longest rod!' Place it on the mat.
slides.mascot_explanation: First, let's pick up the very, very longest red rod. We need to use two hands to hold it, like this! Now, let's put it right here on our mat.

slides.text: Bring all rods to the mat. Scatter them. 'Can you find the longest one?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's bring all the other red rods over to our mat too. We're going to mix them all up, like a jumble! Can you see the *very* longest one?

slides.text: Build the stair: longest at top, each next rod below, aligned at the left edge.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's build a special stair! We put the longest rod at the top. Then, we find the next longest one and put it right underneath, making sure the sides match up. We keep going until we have a beautiful stair!

slides.text: Run your hand down the right side — feel the staircase shape. 'Each rod is a little shorter!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's feel our amazing stair! Put your hand right here on the side and slide it down. See how it goes down, down, down? Each rod is just a little bit shorter than the one before it!

slides.prompt: Mix them up and build the stair again by yourself!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the builder! Let's mix up all the rods again and try to build our red rod stair all by yourself. You can do it!

slides.text: Return each rod to the shelf. 'You built a perfect staircase!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child arrange all 10 rods from longest to shortest?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a wonderful job building the red rod stair! You made it all by yourself! Let's put the rods back carefully. You are so good at seeing how long and short things are!

parent_notes: The Red Rods isolate LENGTH as the only variable — every rod is the same color and width. This is different from the Brown Stair (width) and Pink Tower (three dimensions). Together, these three materials train the eye to discriminate specific attributes. The Red Rods are the precursor to the Number Rods — same dimensions, but with counting segments added.

title: Metal Insets — Square and Triangle
description: Continued metal inset work with the square and triangle shapes. Building pencil control and shape awareness.
instructions:
1. Select the square metal inset.
2. Trace the frame, then the inset. Fill with parallel lines.
3. Repeat with the triangle metal inset.
4. Encourage the child to choose colors.
5. Compare the two designs: 'The square has straight edges. The triangle has three points.'
6. Display the completed designs.

slides.heading: Metal Insets
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this fun activity we get to do today! We're going to play with shapes called a square and a triangle. It's like drawing special pictures with them!

slides.setup_instructions: Let the child choose their colors today.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all the fun things we need! We have a square shape and a triangle shape, and some pretty paper and colorful pencils. You get to pick your favorite colors to make your pictures extra special!

slides.text: 'Today you have two shapes to trace! Which do you want to do first?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Today we get to trace some shapes! See the square and the triangle? You can pick which one you want to trace first. Which one looks like the most fun to you right now?

slides.text: Trace the frame with one color. Trace the inset with a second color. Fill with lines in a third color.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to draw! First, trace the big outside part of the shape with one color. Then, trace the inside shape with a different color. After that, we'll fill it all up with lines using a third color!

slides.text: Repeat with the second shape. Focus on keeping lines straight and close together.
slides.mascot_explanation: We did such a great job with the first shape! Now, let's do the same thing with the other shape, the triangle. Try to make your lines super straight and close together, like little soldiers marching.

slides.prompt: Make both designs. Try to fill inside the lines with careful, close-together parallel lines.
slides.mascot_explanation: It's time to make our special shape pictures! Let's trace and color both the square and the triangle. We need to be very careful and try to fill them up with lines that are close together, like a cozy blanket.

slides.text: 'Beautiful designs! Your pencil control is getting stronger.' Display the work.
slides.mastery_check: Are the child's lines becoming more controlled and closer together?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, you did it! Look at your amazing square and triangle pictures! You are getting so good at drawing carefully and making beautiful designs. Your lines are becoming super strong and steady!

parent_notes: The child may do these quickly or very slowly — both are fine. The goal is the PROCESS of controlled hand movement, not speed. Over weeks, you'll see the filling lines become more parallel, closer together, and more contained within the shape boundaries. This directly translates to handwriting readiness.

title: Number Rods & Numerals — Complete Matching
description: Matching all 10 sandpaper numerals with their corresponding number rods. Connecting abstract symbols to concrete quantities.
instructions:
1. Build the number rod stair 1-10.
2. Shuffle sandpaper numerals 1-10.
3. Pick up a numeral: 'This is 4. Which rod shows four?'
4. Place the numeral at the end of its rod.
5. Let the child match all 10.
6. Count each rod to verify the match is correct.

slides.heading: Number Rods & Numerals
slides.mascot_explanation: Hi friend! Today we're going to play a super fun matching game with numbers and special sticks called number rods. It's like a puzzle where we put everything in its perfect spot!

slides.setup_instructions: Build the rod stair first. Shuffle numerals on the side.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these cool things! We have long sticks called number rods, and bumpy shapes called sandpaper numerals. We also have a big mat to play on. Ask your grown-up to help you find all these things so we can start our game!

slides.text: Build the stair together. 'Now let's give each rod its number name!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, first we're going to build a tall staircase with our number rods, from the shortest one to the longest one. Then, we'll give each rod its special number name so we know which one is which!

slides.text: Demonstrate: pick up numeral 1. 'This says one.' Place it at the right end of rod 1.
slides.mascot_explanation: Watch me! I'm going to pick up this bumpy number. It says "one"! See this little rod? It's the shortest one, so it goes with number one. We put the bumpy number right at the end of its matching rod.

slides.text: 'Your turn! Pick a numeral, read it, and find its matching rod.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the number detective! Pick up a bumpy number, say its name, and then find the rod that looks just like it. You can do it!

slides.prompt: Match all 10! Then play: close your eyes, the parent removes one numeral — which is missing?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, you get to match all the bumpy numbers to their rods all by yourself! You're so good at this. After we match them all, we'll play a guessing game where you find the missing number!

slides.text: 'Every rod has its matching numeral! You connected the rods to the numbers!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child match all 10 numerals to rods independently?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! You matched every single bumpy number to its rod, and now you know what each number looks like! You are such a super matcher, and you learned all about numbers today!

parent_notes: This exercise is pivotal: it connects the CONCRETE (rods you can hold and count) with the ABSTRACT (written numerals). This is the heart of Montessori math — always moving from concrete to abstract. The 'missing numeral' game builds memory and attention. Once matched independently, this becomes a shelf work.

title: Antarctica and All Seven Continents
description: Introducing Antarctica and reviewing all seven continents. Singing the continent song and beginning the world puzzle map.
instructions:
1. Review 6 continents on the globe.
2. Show Antarctica (white): 'This is Antarctica — the coldest place on Earth!'
3. 'Now we know all seven: North America, South America, Europe, Africa, Asia, Australia, Antarctica.'
4. Sing a continent song (to the tune of 'Are You Sleeping?' or 'Frère Jacques').
5. Introduce the world puzzle map if available.
6. Identify each continent piece by its Montessori color.

slides.heading: Seven Continents!
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at the big words! We are going to learn all about the seven continents, and especially a super cold one called Antarctica. It's going to be so much fun learning about our big world together!

slides.setup_instructions: Have the globe out. If you have a puzzle map, place it nearby.
slides.mascot_explanation: Oh, look at all these special things we get to use for our learning adventure! We have a big round globe that shows us our whole world, and sometimes we have a special puzzle map with all the pieces. We also have little cards with pictures of the continents on them.

slides.text: Review: spin the globe slowly. 'Name each continent as my finger touches it!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's spin this globe super slow and look at all the big pieces of land! As I point to each one, can you try to say its name with me? It's like a treasure hunt to find all the continents on our round world.

slides.text: Point to the bottom: 'This is Antarctica — covered in ice! Penguins live here, but no one lives here permanently.'
slides.mascot_explanation: See this big white part all the way at the bottom? That's Antarctica, and it's the coldest place ever, all covered in snow and ice! That's where the cute penguins love to waddle around, but it's too cold for people to live there all the time.

slides.text: All seven together: name each. Sing the continent song if you know one!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we know all seven continents! We have North America, South America, Europe, Africa, Asia, Australia, and our new friend Antarctica. Let's sing our special song about them to help us remember!

slides.prompt: If using a puzzle map: take out each continent piece and name it. Can you put them all back?
slides.mascot_explanation: If we have our special puzzle map, we get to take out each piece of land and say its name. Then, the super fun part is trying to put all the pieces back in their perfect spots! You can be a puzzle master!

slides.text: 'You know all seven continents! What an explorer you are!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child name all 7 continents with visual support (globe)?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! You are such a super explorer because you know all seven continents now! You learned so much about our amazing world, and that's the coolest thing ever!

parent_notes: A simple continent song (many are on YouTube) makes memorization fun. The puzzle map is a wonderful tactile extension — the child physically holds each continent. Don't expect instant recall of all seven; we'll review throughout the year. Make it fun: 'Which continent is the biggest?' 'Which one is cold?' 'Which one do WE live on?'

title: Read-Aloud: Brown Bear, Brown Bear, What Do You See?
description: Shared reading of Bill Martin Jr.'s patterned text, building prediction skills and color/animal vocabulary.
instructions:
1. Read the title. 'What do you think this book is about?'
2. Read aloud with emphasis on the pattern.
3. After a few pages, pause before the answer: 'Brown bear, brown bear, what do you see? I see a ___' Let the child guess.
4. Discuss the colors and animals.
5. After reading, ask: 'What was your favorite animal?'
6. Invite the child to 'read' the pattern back to you.
materials_needed: Brown Bear, Brown Bear, What Do You See? by Bill Martin Jr.
Optional: toy animals matching the book

slides.heading: Read-Aloud
slides.subheading: Brown Bear, Brown Bear, What Do You See?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at the title of our book! It says "Brown Bear, Brown Bear, What Do You See?" It looks like we're going to see some colorful animals in this story!

slides.setup_instructions: Sit together comfortably.
slides.mascot_explanation: We have our special book right here, and some cute little animal toys! These toys are like our friends in the book, and we can hold them while we read. Maybe you can find your favorite animal toy to play with!

slides.text: Show the cover. 'What do you see? What color is this bear?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's look at the very front of our book. See that big, brown bear? What color is he? We're going to talk about what we see on the cover, and what we think the book might be about!

slides.text: Read aloud. Emphasize the repeating pattern. Point to each animal and color.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, we're going to read our story together! Listen to the words, and see if you can hear the part that repeats, like a song. We'll point to the animals and their colors as we go!

slides.text: After 3-4 pages, pause: 'What do you see?' Let the child predict the next animal.
slides.mascot_explanation: We're reading our story, and it's time for a little guessing game! We just saw some animals, and now it's your turn to guess what animal might be coming next. What do *you* think the brown bear sees?

slides.prompt: After reading: 'Now YOU be the reader!' The child 'reads' by remembering the pattern.
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, we finished the story! Now it's your turn to be the reader! Can you remember the special pattern and tell me what the animals see? You can do it!

slides.text: 'You can almost read this book by yourself! Patterns help us predict.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child complete the predictive pattern ('I see a ___ looking at me')?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a great job listening and guessing today! You are getting so good at remembering the pattern and knowing what comes next. You're like a super reader!

parent_notes: Patterned text is a gateway to reading. The repetitive structure lets the child 'read' before they can actually decode — building confidence and love of books. Color words and animal names expand vocabulary. This book can be read dozens of times; each reading builds fluency and memory. A wonderful book for the child to 'read' to a younger sibling or stuffed animal.

title: Hand Washing — Step by Step
description: Learning the complete hand-washing procedure. A fundamental care-of-self exercise in Montessori practical life.
instructions:
1. Set up the hand washing station: basin, pitcher of water, soap, towel, nail brush.
2. Demonstrate each step slowly and deliberately.
3. Roll up sleeves. Pour water over hands. Apply soap.
4. Rub palms, backs of hands, between fingers, thumbs, nails.
5. Rinse thoroughly. Dry with towel.
6. Clean and reset the station.

slides.heading: Hand Washing
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this! We're going to learn how to wash our hands super well. It's called "Care of Self" because taking care of ourselves is very important!

slides.setup_instructions: Set up on a low table or stool. Place a towel underneath to catch drips.
slides.mascot_explanation: We need some special things to wash our hands! See the big bowl? That's a basin to catch the water. We have a little pitcher with warm water, some bubbly soap, a soft towel, and a little brush for our nails. Can you help a grown-up find all these things?

slides.text: Roll up sleeves. 'First we prepare ourselves.' Put on an apron if available.
slides.mascot_explanation: First, we need to get ready! Let's roll up our sleeves so they don't get wet. We want to keep our clothes nice and dry while we wash!

slides.text: Pour water from the pitcher over your hands into the basin. Take the soap. Rub between palms to lather.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's get our hands wet! Carefully pour some water from the pitcher into the basin, right over your hands. Then, pick up the soap and rub your hands together to make lots of foamy bubbles!

slides.text: Wash each part: palms together, back of each hand, between each finger, each thumb, under nails.
slides.mascot_explanation: We need to wash *every* part of our hands. Rub your palms together, then the backs of your hands, and wiggle your fingers to get between them all. Don't forget your thumbs and under your fingernails!

slides.text: Rinse by pouring water over hands. Dry with towel — each finger, palms, backs.
slides.mascot_explanation: Time to rinse! Pour more water over your hands to wash all the soap away. Then, take your towel and dry each finger, your palms, and the backs of your hands until they are all dry.

slides.prompt: Now you do it! Wash your hands following each step. Take your time.
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, now it's your turn to try! You get to wash your hands all by yourself, just like we practiced. Take your time and remember all the steps we learned. You can do it!

slides.text: Pour out the basin water. Hang the towel to dry. 'Your hands are clean and you did it all by yourself!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child complete the hand-washing sequence independently?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did it! You poured out the water and hung up your towel. Look at your clean hands – you washed them all by yourself, and that's amazing!

parent_notes: In Montessori, hand washing is an art form — each step is deliberate and purposeful. It develops independence, sequence memory, and hygiene habits. The standalone station (rather than a bathroom sink) lets the child control the entire process. Over time, the child will do this completely independently. This exercise has obvious health benefits too!

title: First Word Building — CVC with Moveable Alphabet (sat, mat, am)
description: First experience building words with the moveable alphabet! Using known sounds (s, m, a, t), the child builds their first CVC words.
instructions:
1. Set out the moveable alphabet letters: s, m, a, t (several of each).
2. Say: 'I'm going to say a word slowly. Listen for each sound: sss-aaa-t. sat!'
3. 'What's the first sound? /s/! Find the letter s.' Place it on the mat.
4. 'What's the next sound? /a/! Find a.' Place it next to s.
5. 'Last sound? /t/!' Place it. 'You built SAT!'
6. Build: mat, am, at, Sam. Child builds with guidance.
materials_needed: Moveable alphabet (s, m, a, t letters)

slides.heading: Word Building!
slides.subheading: Your First Words with the Moveable Alphabet
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this fun slide! It says "Word Building!" That means we get to play with letters and make real words, just like magic! We're going to learn how to put sounds together to make words, and it's going to be so much fun!

items: Moveable alphabet letters: s, m, a, t
slides.setup_instructions: Lay out the moveable alphabet letters. Place the mat for building.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these little letters! These are special letter tiles, and we use them to build words. We have the letters 's', 'm', 'a', and 't' to play with today. See this big square? That's our building mat where we'll put the letters to make our words. Ask your grown-up to help you get these letters and the mat ready for our game!

slides.text: 'Today is a VERY special day. You're going to build your first WORDS!' The child has earned this.
slides.mascot_explanation: Today is a super special day because you're going to do something amazing! You're going to build your very first words using these letters. It means you're getting so smart and ready to learn how to read!

slides.text: Say 'sat' slowly: /s/ - /a/ - /t/. 'What's the first sound?' Child finds 's'. 'Next sound?' → 'a'. 'Last sound?' → 't'.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, listen super carefully! I'm going to say a word really slowly, and you need to listen for the sounds. The word is 'sat.' Can you hear the first sound? It's /s/! Now, find the letter 's' and put it right here. What's the next sound? It's /a/! Find the letter 'a' and put it next to the 's'. What's the last sound? It's /t/! Find the 't' and put it at the end.

slides.text: Read it together: 's - a - t... sat!' Celebrate! Now build 'mat': /m/ - /a/ - /t/.
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay! We did it! Let's sound it out together: /s/ - /a/ - /t/... sat! You built the word 'sat'! Now, let's try another one. We're going to build the word 'mat'. Listen for the sounds: /m/ - /a/ - /t/. Can you find those letters and put them together on our mat?

slides.prompt: Build these words: am, at, sat, mat, Sam, Tam. Sound out each one as you build it!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the word builder! We're going to make lots of cool words together. Let's try to make 'am', 'at', 'sat', 'mat', and even names like 'Sam' and 'Tam'. Listen for the sounds in each word and find the letters to build them on your mat. You can do it!

slides.text: 'You are a WORD BUILDER! You can make words with letters!' Photograph the words.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child build at least 2 CVC words with support?
slides.mascot_explanation: You are such a super word builder! You learned how to take sounds and put letters together to make real words. Isn't that amazing? We built words like 'sat' and 'mat' and even names! You're doing a fantastic job learning to read!

parent_notes: THIS IS A MILESTONE! The child is encoding — translating sounds to symbols. This is writing before handwriting! In Montessori, children write (build words) before they read. Don't expect the child to READ these words yet — the skill here is BUILDING them from sounds they hear. Celebrate enthusiastically. Some children will be amazed; some will be matter-of-fact. Both responses are fine.

title: Number Rod & Numeral Matching — Independence
description: Independent practice with number rod and numeral matching. The child works through the full matching exercise on their own.
instructions:
1. Invite the child to take out the number rods and numerals.
2. 'Today, I'd like YOU to do the whole matching by yourself.'
3. Observe without intervening.
4. Only assist if the child asks or becomes frustrated.
5. When complete, verify together by counting each rod.
6. 'You did the whole thing independently!'

slides.heading: Number Rods & Numerals
slides.mascot_explanation: Hi friend! Look, today we're going to play a fun matching game all by ourselves. It's called Number Rods and Numerals, and it's like a puzzle just for you!

slides.setup_instructions: The child carries everything to the mat independently.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these cool things we need! We have long colorful rods, like big blocks, and little number cards. We also have a soft mat to put everything on. Can you ask a grown-up to help you get all these special things ready?

slides.text: 'Today you get to do this all by yourself! Build the stair and match the numerals.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, now it's your turn to be the builder! We need to make a colorful stair with the rods, and then find the right number card for each step. You get to do this whole part all by yourself!

slides.text: Observe quietly. Resist the urge to correct. Note any rods or numerals placed incorrectly.
slides.mascot_explanation: Shhh, let's be super quiet helpers now. We just watch you play and learn. It's like magic watching you figure out where everything goes!

slides.text: If the child makes an error and doesn't notice: after completion, count together to verify.
slides.mascot_explanation: If you make a little oopsie and don't see it, that's okay! We can count together at the very end to make sure all the numbers are just right.

slides.prompt: Do the complete exercise independently: build the stair, match all numerals, then verify by counting.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time for the big matching puzzle! You get to build the whole stair and put all the number cards where they belong. Take your time, you can do it!

slides.text: 'Wonderful independent work! You did that all on your own.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child complete the exercise independently with no more than 1 error?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay! You did it all by yourself! That was amazing independent work, I'm so proud of you for building and matching all the numbers on your own!

parent_notes: This is a test of independence — a core Montessori value. Sit nearby but don't intervene. Mistakes are learning opportunities; the child may self-correct when counting to verify. If they don't, gently count together: 'Let's check — this rod has... one, two, three, four, five, six. And this numeral says... seven. Hmm, do those match?' Let the child discover and fix the error.

title: Sink or Float — Simple Experiment
description: A hands-on science experiment exploring which objects sink and which float. The child makes predictions and tests them.
instructions:
1. Fill a basin with water.
2. Gather 8-10 objects: rock, leaf, cork, coin, plastic toy, apple, key, sponge, wooden block, paper clip.
3. For each object: 'Do you think this will sink or float?' Record the prediction.
4. Test it! Drop the object in the water.
5. Was the prediction correct?
6. Sort tested objects into 'sink' and 'float' groups.
7. Discuss: 'What do the floating things have in common?'

slides.heading: Sink or Float?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at that! Today we get to be super scientists and do a fun experiment all about sinking and floating. We're going to learn if things go down to the bottom or stay on top of the water.

items: Assorted objects: rock, leaf, cork, coin, toy, apple, key, sponge, block, paper clip
slides.setup_instructions: Fill the basin. Lay out objects and a towel. Prepare a simple chart: two columns labeled 'sink' and 'float.'
slides.mascot_explanation: To be scientists, we need our special tools! We have a big tub of water, lots of cool things to test like a rock and a toy, and a towel to dry our hands. We also have paper to write down our amazing guesses! Ask your grown-up to help you get all these things ready for our adventure.

slides.text: 'Scientists make predictions — guesses about what will happen — and then test them!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Being a scientist means making smart guesses, called predictions, about what will happen. It's like guessing what's inside a present before you open it! We get to guess if each thing will sink or float before we even try it.

slides.text: Hold up the first object (rock). 'Will this sink or float? What do you think?' Record the guess.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's look at this first thing – it's a rock! Do you think this heavy rock will go down, down, down to the bottom, or will it stay right on top of the water? Let's think hard and make our best guess!

slides.text: 'Let's find out!' Drop it in the water. 'It sank! Were you right?' Continue with each object.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now for the exciting part! We get to see if our guess was right. Let's gently put the rock in the water and watch what happens! We'll see if it sinks or floats, and then we'll see if we guessed correctly.

slides.prompt: Test all the objects! Make your prediction first, then test. How many did you get right?
slides.mascot_explanation: It's time to be a super scientist and test all the things! For each one, first make your smart guess about sinking or floating, and then plop it in the water to see! Let's count how many of our guesses were just right.

slides.text: Dry objects off. 'What did you notice about the things that floated? They were mostly light or had air in them!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child make predictions and describe why some objects float?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, we did it! We tested all our things and saw what happens. Look at the things that floated – they were all light and airy, like the leaf! You are such a great scientist for figuring this out.

parent_notes: This is the scientific method in its simplest form: hypothesize (predict), test (experiment), and analyze (discuss results). Don't worry about teaching 'density' at this age — the intuitive experience of seeing heavy things sink and light things float builds the foundation. Some results will surprise the child (an apple floats!) — these surprises are the best learning moments.

title: Music Appreciation — Listening to Classical Music
description: Guided listening experience with a piece of classical music. The child learns to listen actively and express what the music makes them feel.
instructions:
1. Choose a short classical piece (suggested: Vivaldi's 'Spring' from The Four Seasons, 3-4 minutes).
2. 'We're going to listen to music and see what we notice.'
3. Play the piece once — just listen.
4. 'How did that make you feel? Was it fast or slow? Loud or soft?'
5. Play again — this time, draw while listening.
6. 'What did you draw? How does it connect to the music?'

slides.heading: Music Appreciation
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at that! Today, we're going to have a special time listening to music. It's called "Music Appreciation," and we'll learn all about listening carefully to beautiful songs.

slides.setup_instructions: Set up in a quiet space. Have drawing materials ready but set aside for first listen.
slides.mascot_explanation: To make our music time super fun, we need a few things! We need something to play the music, like a special box or a phone, and we need some paper and colorful crayons for drawing. Maybe your grown-up can help you find these things and get them ready for us.

slides.text: 'Today we're going to LISTEN to a beautiful piece of music. Close your eyes and listen.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, now it's time for our first listen! We're going to close our eyes for just a little bit and listen very, very carefully to a beautiful song. Let's see what sounds we can hear when we're super quiet.

slides.text: Play the piece (3-4 minutes). Sit quietly together. Model attentive listening.
slides.mascot_explanation: Shhh, listen! This is the music playing just for us. Let's sit here quietly and listen with our ears wide open. We're going to hear something very pretty.

slides.text: 'What did you hear? Was it fast or slow? Loud or quiet? How did it make you feel?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now that we've heard the music, let's talk about it! Was the music fast like a bunny hopping, or slow like a turtle walking? Was it loud like a lion roaring, or soft like a whisper? How did it make your body feel?

slides.prompt: Listen again — this time, draw what the music makes you see or feel. Let your crayon dance to the music!
slides.mascot_explanation: This time, we get to draw while the music plays again! Let your crayon move however the music makes you want to move. If the music is fast, maybe your crayon can zoom! If it's slow, maybe it can tiptoe.

slides.text: 'Your drawing is music you can see! Different music makes us feel different things.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child describe at least one quality of the music (fast/slow, loud/soft)?
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at your wonderful drawing! You made music that we can see! It's so cool how music can make us feel happy or excited, and how it can sound fast or slow. You did such a great job listening!

parent_notes: Music appreciation is a lifelong gift. Start with short, expressive pieces. Vivaldi's Four Seasons, Saint-Saens' Carnival of the Animals, and Prokofiev's Peter and the Wolf are all wonderful for young children. There's no wrong response — if the music makes them want to dance, let them dance! The goal is engaged, active listening rather than passive background music.
